Scaling down to 10 people instead of 100 makes it easy to substitute playing cards as stand-ins for the boxes. If you would like to manually simulate the bet, as stated, for a group of 10 people then you can do the following. Take 10 regular playing cards ( numbered cards 1 (the Ace) through 10, all diamonds if you like since we're simulating a money bet ), shuffle and deal all 10 cards face down from left to right. The left most card will be considered as being in position-location 1, the next card to the right will be located in position-location 2, etc.. Now assume you are person_one and you're hoping to find the "1 card"  (the Ace). So, as person_one, you start by turning over the card in position-location 1. If you just turned over the Ace then your part is done (as persone_one)  and person_one can leave the room. Now, ensure that all ten cards are put back to their original starting condition (reseted, all are face down again) without changing card locations, and now person_two can enter the room. Otherwise, your still playing as person_one if the card you turned over was not an Ace. Now you (person_one) still have four more turns (guesses) remaining. Each person(x)  has 5 guess-turns apiece, since 5 (guess-turns) is half of 10 (people), just as 50 (guess-turns) is half of 100 (people). Now if you, as person_one, turned over a 2-card (for example) on the first turn, then the next card you will turn over will be the card that is in position-location 2, if it was a 3-card then you'll turn over the card in position-location 3.  ( Suggestion, placing small paper squares numbered 1 - 10 beside each respective position-location helps quite a bit). In either case, if your person_one's second-guess card is an Ace, then person one found his/her card, otherwise keep hunting for the Ace in this fashion until you have used up all of person_one's five turns. If you found the Ace during this time then your done, mission accomplished for person_one and person_two will be up next trying to find the 2-card  first turning the card over in position-location 2. That is, after the cards have all been turn back over face-down and person_one has left the room. If person_one did not find the Ace in 5 turns, then the game is over and the same 10 cards will be reshuffled and you can start the next bet-game. Mark the win_lose result on a piece of paper. You should wind up winning about 35% of the time with a group of ten players, that is, about one-third of the time all ten players, almost unbelievably, will each 'guess' their respectively numbered card during the same game played! Playing a game all the way through to the 10th person only takes about 5 minutes.
After the 10th person has found their respective card then the whole group wins!

With the introduction of another variable (say time), we can get a 50% chance of winning. Say if the prisoners line up one after the other to enter the room, and say the prisoner can stay in the room for as long as he wants, the strategy can be the following:

The boxes are split "left side" (box 1-50) and "right side" (box 51-100). Beforehand, prisoner 1 tells everyone he will pick the left side, if he gets it wrong, everyone dies. But if he picks it right, he has the next task of finding ticket #2 out of those 50 boxes in the left side. If he does find ticket #2 on the "left side", he stays in the room and wait for 15 mins. If he doesn't find ticket #2 that must mean the "right side" contains ticket #2, and he exits the room immediately. 

With the extra piece of information (waiting in line for an extra 15 mins), prisoner #2 and every prisoner waiting in line now knows if ticket #2 is on the "left side" or the "right side". Say ticket  #2 is on the "right side", entering the room, prisoner #2 will open box 51-100 and find his ticket. He is also happens to find ticket #3, he stays in the room and wait for 15 mins, otherwise, he exits immediately. 

Prisoner #3 and every prisoner waiting in line now know which side ticket #3 is. The process is repeated and everyone finds their ticket.

This solution is similar to solution for the "Prisoners and hats puzzle": http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prisoners_and_hats_puzzle
